history.content:
I would only recommend this schedule if you have done well in probability/linear algebra (i.e. CS70/54 or more advanced courses), and/or have taken heavy workloads in the past. If you are really rusty/weak in either probability or linear algebra, I would recommend pushing back either 126 or 127 respectively, and take an intermediate course (Stat 140 or Math 110). Of course, if you really know how to manage your time, then you can have a weaker background, and vice versa.

That being said, this schedule is not uncommon. 110 and 127 do overlap, and go well together; 127 is the harder class, and I found that 127 helped more with 110 than the other way around, just because of the difficulty. 126 is weekly problem sets, and briefly recaps the probability material from CS70 in the first couple weeks. 126 is also one of the most organized upper divs, making it a bit more manageable. 127 on the other hand can require much more independent studying; the lectures are relatively surface level, and you might have to read on your own to truly understand what's going on. 110 for the most part is a slightly harder 54.

All in all, its doable if you know how to manage your time and/or have a solid background in probability/lin alg.

children.subject: Don't take 126 after taking 140 or vice versa. The content is extremely redundant. If you took CS70, just take 126. CS70, 126, and 140 is just overkill.

Each of these three courses are problem set courses, so it will suck pretty bad. 

While 127 and 110 complement each other, I found it was better for me to take them in different semesters, so that what you learn in one can help with the other. In a different experience than the student response, I found taking Math110 first and then 127 to be more helpful, because I found that 127 assumed you already experience writing strong linear algebra proofs, while 110 built my (nonexistent) proof writing skills from the ground up. 

If you have a strong linear algebra or proof writing background, then don't hesitate to launch into 127. But if your lin alg/ proofs are shaking, consider taking 110 first. 

I also agree with other followup - all three of 70, 140, and 126 is too much overlap - two of the three is sufficient. Which one you choose of 140/126 depends on your current comfort with probability and whether you are more interested in EE or DS applications.

history.content: Planning on taking this schedule in the spring. Would this be doable? I imagine that 110 and 127 would overlap a lot in the beginning at least.
history.subject: Math 110+EECS 126+EECS 127?
